example-learning-objective.text: Prose we want to show up in the lesson.
example-learning-objective.assessment-rec: author notes about how it might be assessed

table-build-column.text: Add a column to a table.
table-build-column.assessment-rec: Give students a starter-file with a table and have them add a column

table-filter.text: Filter a table using a Boolean-producing function.
table-filter.assessment-rec: Give students a starter-file with a table and have them filter it.

stdev-understand.text: Use standard deviation to make judgments about data, and understand the role it plays in those judgements.
stdev-understand.assessment-rec: Compare two datasets, their means and stdevs, and a conclusion that ignores the stdev. Ask students why the conclusion is wrong

stdev-calc.text: Calculate the standard deviation of a dataset.
stdev-calc.assessment-rec: Give students a dataset, have them calculate the stdev

boxplot-create.text: Compute the 5-number summary and draw the box plot for a given dataset.
boxplot-create.assessment-rec: Give students a dataset, have them calculate the 5-number summary and draw a box plot

spread-transfer.text: Compare and contrast information displayed in a box plot and a histogram, identifying that box plots have variable intervals and histograms have fixed bins.
spread-transfer.assessment-rec: Have students match box plots to histograms

histograms-pyret.text: Create histograms from a dataset in Pyret.

random-sample-pyret.text: Use Pyret to generate differently sized random samples from a dataset.

measures-of-center-pyret.text: Compute measures of center including mean, median and mode(s) of a dataset in Pyret.

measures-of-spread-pyret.text: Compute measures of spread of a dataset including range and IQR in Pyret.

categorical-displays-pyret.text: Create categorical displays from a single column of a dataset in Pyret (i.e. pie charts, bar charts).

compound-categorical-displays-pyret.text: Create categorical displays from two columns of a dataset in Pyret (i.e. multi-bar charts, stacked-bar charts).

pros-cons-bar-pie.text: Recognize that while pie charts and bar charts both display the counts of categorical data, consideration should be given to which is a more useful display for a given situation.

interpret-bar.text: Interpret bar charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

interpret-pie.text: Interpret pie charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

interpret-stacked-bar.text: Interpret stacked bar charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

interpret-multi-bar.text: Interpret multi-bar charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

sensible-grouped-samples.text: Identify sensible grouped samples for a dataset.

develop-statistical-question.text: Develop a statistical research question about a real-world dataset.

cat-v-quant-def.text: Explain the difference between Categorical and Quantitative data, recognizing that Quantitative data measures an amount while Categorical data is used to qualify.

cat-v-quant-variable.text: Identify whether a variable in a dataset is Categorical or Quantitative by considering whether the data tells us "what kind?" or "how much?"

use-contracts.text: Use contracts to write expressions that will produce one-variable displays in Pyret (pie charts, bar charts, histograms, and box plots).

read-contracts.text: Make sense of functions in @proglang by interpreting their contracts.

infographic-ratios.text: Assess whether various infographics effectively incorporate ratios and proportions by considering the infographic's impact.

infographic-stereotypes.text: Avoid stereotyping when creating an infographic in order to help viewers relate to and understand the topic.

data-cycle-parts.text: Describe the four parts of the Data Cycle, including: (1) ask questions, (2) consider the data, (3) analyze the data, and (4) interpret the data.

stat-inference.text: Explain how statistical inference uses information from a sample (e.g., probability) to draw conclusions about the larger population from which the sample was taken.

sample-size.text: Describe the role of sample size, recognizing that larger samples generally yield better estimates of what's true for a population.

random-sample-bias.text: Describe how random sampling can help us avoid bias in our analysis.

describe-data-cycle.text: Describe the four parts of the Data Cycle, including: (1) ask questions, (2) consider the data, (3) analyze the data, and (4) interpret the data.

rows-and-columns.text: Identify the specific Rows and Columns needed to answer various questions.

describe-dataset.text: Describe a dataset by discussing its source, structure, and relevance.

define-subsets.text: Define tables of differently sized subsets from a dataset in Pyret.

explanatory-response.text: Differentiate between an explanatory variable and a response variable, recognizing that the response variable (plotted on the y-axis) responds to the explanatory variable (plotted on the x-axis).

scatter-plots-by-hand.text: Make scatter plots by hand given a list of (x,y) pairs

trends-in-scatter-plots.text: Identify possible trends in scatter-plots by exploring relationships between columns.

unusual-observations.text: Understand that unusual observations are always worth thinking about: sometimes they are random, sometimes they provide deeper insight, and sometimes are the points we are looking for.
